Understate: The claim may understate the role of the University of Wisconsin-Madison in the invention of Social Security by stating that it was "basically invented" there.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to conclusively prove that Social Security was invented at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the origin of Social Security that are not mentioned in the provided information.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Franklin Roosevelt appointed Edwin Witte and Arthur Altmeyer, both graduates and professors at UW-Madison, to key roles in the development of Social Security.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Franklin Roosevelt got the idea for Social Security from the University of Wisconsin-Madison without providing sufficient evidence to support this assumption.
